bibl.title: Lewis Johnson v. Defendant. Witness Testimony, Frankie Russell.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21: US District Court, Western Division of Washington, Seatle

div1.p: called as a witness, being first sworn, testified as follows:
96 Q. You live in the same house, or rather the last witness lives in the same house you do? A. Yes
97 Q. Do you know Lewis Johnston? A. Yes
98 Q. How long have you known him? A. I have known him about six months.

99 Q. Will you tell us shortly what happened on Saturday, that would be the 4th of June and from then on as far as you personally know about it? A. Johnston came to our house between 4 and 5 in the morning and knocked on the door. I told him first we were in bed; he said it was important, that he wanted to see Mr. Tate. I opened the door and let him in and called Mr. Tate; and him and Mr Tate were talking and my- self. He had a bottle of gin with him and some fancy cigarettes and a bottle of cream, and he said that the reason he said it was important he thought we would not let him in. We drank there for awhile, and he asked Mr. Tate if he would go up-town to get him some underwear and shoes. Mr Tate said he would. He wanted Mr. Tate to go up-town with him. He said "what is the object of going up-town so early in the morning?" and he said "I have to see Garnett before Garnett goes to bed." The rest he knows. He came back to the house and he crank a considerable bit, and when I
